Parking Lot Photographs and Related Publications
1949-1988
PR 451Collection processed by Joseph Ditta (November-December 2022)New-York Historical SocietyNew-York Historical Society170 Central Park WestNew York, NY 10024(212) 873-3400This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2022-12-28T17:13:02Finding aid written in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard The documents in this collection are in English.
New-York Historical Society
New York City Department of Traffic parking lot photographs and related publications
New York (N.Y.). Department of Traffic.
PR 451
4 Linear feet in 4 record cartons.
1949-1988 Photographs of sites of projected and existing municipal parking lots and garages operated by the New York City Department of Traffic throughout the five boroughs. Some views show street parking conditions, towing and auto body shops, traffic congestion, and pedestrian safety posters. A number of photographs capture areas of the city that have since become unrecognizable through early 21st-century gentrification and building projects. The collection includes approximately ninety supplementary publications such as feasibility studies, master plans, and neighborhood redevelopment proposals for some of the locations documented by the photographs. This collection is stored offsite. For information on making arrangements to consult it, please go to www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Access Restrictions
This collection is stored offsite. For information on making arrangements to consult it, please go to www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Joel Tolchinsky, 2022.
Arrangement
The collection is organized by format in two series:
Series I.
Photographs, 1958-1979
Series II.
Publications, 1949-1988
Historical note
Formed to oversee tasks originally controlled by the New York Police Department, the New York City Department of Traffic, under its first commissioner, Thomas T. Wiley (1950–1961), instituted strict parking rules, changed some streets from two-way traffic to one, and installed the first parking meters (1951). To free the city's congested streets and to generate revenue in busy shopping and business districts, the department began building municipal parking lots and garages. The first garage appeared in Flushing, Queens, in 1954, followed in the 1960s and '70s by others in Jamaica, Queens, Downtown Brooklyn, East 153rd Street in the Bronx, and Eighth Avenue at West 53rd Street in Manhattan. Today, Manhattan alone boasts some 100,000 off-street parking spaces in about 1,600 facilities, some of them managed by the Department of Transportation, which succeeded the Department of Traffic in 1977.
[For further information, see Sigurd Grava, "Parking" and "Traffic" in The Encyclopedia of New York City, 2nd edition (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2010). The Green Book: Official Directory of New York City lists city-operated parking facilities for various years.]
Preferred Citation
The collection should be cited as: New York City Department of Traffic Parking Lot Photographs and Related Publications, PR 451, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, New-York Historical Society.
Processing Information
Archivist Joseph Ditta arranged and described this collection in November-December 2022.
Scope and Contents
The New York City Department of Traffic Parking Lot Photographs and Related Publications document the sites of projected and existing municipal parking lots and garages (some during construction) maintained by that agency throughout the five boroughs. Beyond these the collection's photographs (1958-1979) show street parking conditions and traffic congestion, and in some instances capture neighborhood scenes that have been so drastically changed by 21st century building projects as to be virtually unrecognizable today. The approximately ninety publications (1949-1988) supplementing the photographs—some of which were issued by the Department of Traffic, others by related city and state agencies—include feasibility studies, master plans, and redevelopment proposals for areas like Fulton Arcade (Brooklyn), Little Italy (Manhattan), and Jamaica Center (Queens).
Use Restrictions
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.
Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

Series I. Photographs1958-1979
Scope and Contents
Photographs of sites of projected and existing municipal parking lots and garages—some during construction and after completion—administered by the New York City Department of Traffic, as well as views of street parking conditions, towing and auto body shops, traffic congestion, and pedestrian safety posters.
Arrangement
Series I is organized in six subseries. Files within each subseries are listed alphabetically. Titles in [brackets] were devised by the archivist.Subseries I.A.
Photographs: New York City-wide and elsewhere, 1965-1971Subseries I.B.
Photographs: Bronx, 1962-1974Subseries I.C.
Photographs: Brooklyn, 1962-1975Subseries I.D.
Photographs: Manhattan, 1963-1972Subseries I.E.
Photographs: Queens, 1958-1979Subseries I.F.
Photographs: Staten Island, 1962-1963Subseries I.A. Photographs: New York City-wide and elsewhere1965-1971Equipment, Univac[1966 July 27?]11

Interior views of an unidentified parking garage, with closeups of car fenders and bumpers. The date on the original folder may not apply to when the photographs were taken.New York City—Transit Strike[1966 August 10?]12
Scope and Contents
The date on the original folder may not apply to when this single photograph was taken. The 1966 New York City transit strike occurred in January.[Parking Field Sites]undated13
Scope and Contents
Original folder labeled "Parking Field Sites 39 St. & 2 Ave." Contains views of unidentified parking lots and structures around New York City. Images of identifiable locations have been removed and filed under their respective boroughs.[Photo duplication list][1971]14
Scope and Contents
Original folder labeled "Duplicate Pictures of Proposed Garages." Contains no photographs, only a handwritten list of "Pictures in Files," some of which were sent "for photography" on December 9, 1971.[Safety and promotional photos][1962], 1970 July 1, undated15
Scope and Contents
Photographs of Traffic Department Safety Education Program posters with such slogans as "Look Before You Cross . . . at the Corners, Of Course" and "Mickey Mantle Says -- Play it Safe! Cross at Corners, Not mid block." Includes an image of traffic / transit officials posed with a cartoon drawing of an anthropomorphized computer on which are the words "The Best Thing That's Happened To Parking Tickets Since Disappearing Ink." One image published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).Taxi[s]1968 June 12, 18, 2716

Scope and Contents
Approximately ninety publications, some issued by the Department of Traffic, others by related New York City and State agencies, supplementing the locations documented in the photographs of Series I.
Arrangement
Series II is organized in six subseries. Files within each subseries are listed chronologically.Subseries II.A.
